title: Rolled-Up Newspaper

verbs: Publicize widely or highly, as if with a headline
To move by turning over or rotating.
Move by turning over or rotating
To cause to revolve by turning over and over; to move by turning on an axis; to impel forward by causing to turn over and over on a supporting surface.
To engage in the business of journalism (usually used only in the gerund, newspapering)
nouns: A daily or weekly publication on folded sheets; contains news and articles and advertisements
A newspaper is a periodical publication containing news, other informative articles, and usually advertising.
A periodical publication
A newspaper which appears in the evening.
A daily or twice daily published publication (usually printed on cheap, low-quality paper) that contains news and other articles.
Scheduled publication containing news of events, articles, features, editorials, and advertising
A publication, usually published daily or weekly and usually printed on cheap, low-quality paper, containing news and other articles.
A publication (usually published daily or weekly and printed on cheap, low-quality paper) that contains news and other articles.
Newspapers are periodical publications containing news regarding current events, informative articles, diverse features, editorials, and advertising.
"media coverage"), the communication of selected information on current events
Communication of selected information on current events
News is the communication of selected information on current events which is presented by print, broadcast, Internet, or word of mouth to a third party or mass audience.
New information of interest.
Information reported in a newspaper or news magazine
News is the communication of selected information on current events.
New information.
The heading or caption of a newspaper article
A heading or title of an article.
A heading or caption subordinate to a main headline, heading, or title especially when inserted as a divider between sections (as of a newspaper or periodical article or story or text of a book)
Text indicating the nature of the article below it
Heading or title of an article.
The headline is the text indicating the nature of the article below it.
A subordinate heading in an outline (in a document, worksheet or other).
Text at the top of a newspaper article
A material made of cellulose pulp derived mainly from wood or rags or certain grasses
A sheet material used for writing on or printing on (or as a non-waterproof container), usually made by draining cellulose fibres from a suspension in water.
Material for writing on.
Material mainly used for writing upon, printing upon, drawing or for packaging
Felted or matted sheets of cellulose fibers, formed on a fine-wire screen from a dilute water suspension, and bonded together as the water is removed and the sheet is dried.
Paper is a thin material produced by pressing together moist fibers, typically cellulose pulp derived from wood, rags or grasses, and drying them into flexible sheets.

description:
A newspaper rolled up and bound, as for delivery to a house. Generally positioned at a 45° angle. Commonly used for various content concerning news, media, and journalism as well as personal news.

See also üì∞ Newspaper.
apple_vendor_description: Apple's rolled-up newspaper emoji appears as a tightly bound scroll of newsprint, tied with a simple string and casting a subtle shadow that adds to its realistic 3D feel.  The texture of the paper is subtly suggested through soft gradients, making it a tactile representation of information and current events on Apple devices.  This emoji is ideal for signaling breaking news, discussions, or sharing articles and insights.
